ben.ladalja

Class Model

  • java.lang.Object
    • ben.ladalja.Model

  • public abstract class Model
extends java.lang.Object
    Ladalja provides a beautiful, simple ActiveRecord implementation for working with your database.
    Each database table has a corresponding "Model" which is used to interact with that table.
    Model allow you to query for data in your tables, as well as insert new records into the table.

    To create a model, your model class must extends Model, and All field must be classes, thus use Integer instead of int Do not use Character class, use String instead You can use Column and Ignore annotations To handle relationships, do not declare a model class into other, declare only method to set and get, in those methods you will use Ladalja relationships Redefine getTable() to return the name of table that this model is being represented Eventually override getPrimaryKey() to return primary key column name, the default implementation return "id"

    For example, let consider three classe, Game,User and Role
    User and Role have many to many relationship, thus User have and belongs to many Role and Role have and belongs to many User
    User have many game
    Game belong to one user

    • The Game table is "game" (id,name,user_id)
    • The Role table is "role" (id,name)
    • The User table is "users" (ID,name)
    • The User-Role relationship table is "role_users" (user_id,role_id)

    An example of implementations of this situation can be like that 

     public class Game extends Model {
        
                private Long id;
                @Column("user_id") 
                private Long userId;
                private String name;
        
        
                @Override
                protected String getTable() {
                        return "games";
                }
        
                public User getUser() {
                        return belongsTo(User.class, "user_id"); //see belongsTo(Class, String) for details
                }
 
                public Long getId() { //public void long getId()... will not work use class like you are seeing
                        return id;
                }
  

                public void setId(Long id) { //public void setId(long id)... will not work use class like you are seeing
                        this.id = id;
                }
        
                //Other getter and setter

        }
        

      public class Role extends Model {

                private Long id;
                private String name;
                
                @Override
                protected String getTable() {
                        return "roles";
                }
                
                public List<User> getUsers() {
                        return belongsToMany(User.class, "role_users", "user_id", "role_id"); //see belongsToMany(Class, String, String, String) for details
                }
                
                public void setUsers(List<User> users) {
                        for(User user : users)
                                attach("user_roles", "role_id", "user_id", user); //see attach(String, String, String, Model) for details
                }

                //Other getters and setters
                
        }
  

      public class User extends Model {

                private Long id;
                private String name;
                
                @Override
                protected String getTable() {
                        return "roles";
                }

                @Override
                protected String getPrimaryKey(){       //primary key is not "id", so we have to indicated it
                        return "ID";
                }
                
                public List<Game> getGames() {
                        return this.hasMany(Game.class, "user_id"); //see hasMany(Class, String) for details
                }

                public List<Role> getRoles() {
                        return this.belongsToMany(Role.class, "role_users", "role_id", "user_id");
                }
                
                public void setGames(List<Game> games) {
                        for(Game game : games)
                                game = associate(game,"user_id"); //see associate(Model, String) for details
                }

                //Other getters and setters
                
        }

    An Example of using is

    User user = User.find(User.class, 1);
    List<Game> games = user.getGames();

    List<User> users = User.where("name","<>","Admin").get(User.class);
    Role role = Role.where("name", "user").first(Role.class);
    role.setUsers(users);

    You can have detail in used method in example here :

    • find(Class, Object)
    • where(String, String, Object)
    • where(String, Object)
    • first(Class)

      To attach a model A to a model B by inserting a record in the intermediate table that joins the models
      static java.lang.Double avg(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> model, java.lang.String column) 
      <T extends Model>
      T      		 belongsTo(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel, java.lang.String foreignKey)
      The inverse of one-to-one relationship, this is inverse of hosOne method The first argument passed to the hasOne method is the class of the related model We determines the foreign key of the relationship with the foreignKey argument We assumes that the primary key of parent (retrieved with getPrimaryKey() method of parent) should have a value matching the foreign key of this object Otherwise null will be returned (in case of there is no matching)
      <T extends Model>
      java.util.List<T>      		 belongsToMany(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel, java.lang.String relationshipJoiningTable, java.lang.String foreignKey, java.lang.String joiningForeignKey)
      A "many-to-many" relationship which is used when a model A owns any amount of other model B and model B owns also any amount model A To define this relationship, three database tables are needed: model A table, model B table and joining table.

      <T extends Model>
      java.util.List<T>      		 hasMany(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel, java.lang.String foreignKey)
      A "one-to-many" relationship which is used to define relationships where a single model owns any amount of other models In that case a single model is this object.
      <T extends Model>
      T      		 hasOne(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel, java.lang.String foreignKey)
      A "one-to-one" relationship is a very basic relation The first argument passed to the hasOne method is the class of the related model We determines the foreign key of the relationship with the foreignKey argument We assumes that the foreign key should have a value matching the primary key (retrieved with getPrimaryKey() method) of the parent Otherwise null will be returned (in case of there is no matching)

    • Method Detail

      • save

        public void save()
        To create a new record in the database, create a new model instance, set attributes on the model, then call the save method. The save method may also be used to update models that already exist in the database. To update a model, you should retrieve it, set any attributes you wish to update, and then call the save method

      • delete

        public void delete()
        Call this method on a model instance to delete a model.

        QueryBuilder.havingRaw(java.lang.String)

      • hasOne

        public <T extends Model> T hasOne(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel,
                                  java.lang.String foreignKey)
        A "one-to-one" relationship is a very basic relation The first argument passed to the hasOne method is the class of the related model We determines the foreign key of the relationship with the foreignKey argument We assumes that the foreign key should have a value matching the primary key (retrieved with getPrimaryKey() method) of the parent Otherwise null will be returned (in case of there is no matching)
        Parameters:
        relatedModel - the class of the related model
        foreignKey - the foreign key of the relationship
        Returns:
        a new instance of relatedModel class or null

      • belongsTo

        public <T extends Model> T belongsTo(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel,
                                     java.lang.String foreignKey)
        The inverse of one-to-one relationship, this is inverse of hosOne method The first argument passed to the hasOne method is the class of the related model We determines the foreign key of the relationship with the foreignKey argument We assumes that the primary key of parent (retrieved with getPrimaryKey() method of parent) should have a value matching the foreign key of this object Otherwise null will be returned (in case of there is no matching)
        Parameters:
        relatedModel - the class of the related model
        foreignKey - the foreign key of the relationship
        Returns:
        a new instance of relatedModel class or null
        See Also:
        hasOne(Class, String)

      • hasMany

        public <T extends Model> java.util.List<T> hasMany(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel,
                                                   java.lang.String foreignKey)
        A "one-to-many" relationship which is used to define relationships where a single model owns any amount of other models In that case a single model is this object.
        Parameters:
        relatedModel - the model class that this object owns any amount
        foreignKey - the foreign key of the relationship
        Returns:
        list of matching objects

      • belongsToMany

        public <T extends Model> java.util.List<T> belongsToMany(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> relatedModel,
                                                         java.lang.String relationshipJoiningTable,
                                                         java.lang.String foreignKey,
                                                         java.lang.String joiningForeignKey)
        A "many-to-many" relationship which is used when a model A owns any amount of other model B and model B owns also any amount model A To define this relationship, three database tables are needed: model A table, model B table and joining table. The first parameter is the model class which represent B model, ie the model class that we wants to get from this object. The second parameter is the name of that joining table. In the joining table there are two fields, A primary key and B primary key, the names of those columns are respectively the third and last parameters Thus third parameter is the name of column representing the primary key of this object while the last parameter is which one represent the primary key of relatedModel class primary key.
        Parameters:
        relatedModel - the model class that this object owns any amount
        relationshipJoiningTable - the relationship's joining table name
        foreignKey - the name of primary key representing column of this object is relationship's joining table
        joiningForeignKey - the name of primary key representing column of relatedModel class object is relationship's joining table
        Returns:
        list of relatedModel object or empty list if there are no matching.

      • associate

        public <T extends Model> T associate(T instance,
                                     java.lang.String foreignKey)
        Convenient method for adding new model to relationship

        For example, perhaps you need to insert a new Comment for a Post model.

        Instead of manually setting the post_id attribute on the Comment id, you may insert the Comment directly from the relationship's with method

        Parameters:
        instance - the instance of T model class you to associate to this object
        foreignKey - of the relationship
        Returns:
        an updated instance

      • attach

        public <T extends Model> void attach(java.lang.String relationshipJoiningTable,
                                     java.lang.String foreignKey,
                                     java.lang.String joiningForeignKey,
                                     T instance)
        To attach a model A to a model B by inserting a record in the intermediate table that joins the models
        Parameters:
        relationshipJoiningTable - the name of relationship joining table
        foreignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for this object
        joiningForeignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for instance
        instance - the related model instance
        See Also:
        belongsToMany(Class, String, String, String)

      • detach

        public <T extends Model> void detach(java.lang.String relationshipJoiningTable,
                                     java.lang.String foreignKey,
                                     java.lang.String joiningForeignKey,
                                     T... instances)
        To detach a model A to a model B by inserting a record in the intermediate table that joins the models
        Parameters:
        relationshipJoiningTable - the name of relationship joining table
        foreignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for this object
        joiningForeignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for instances model
        instances - the related model instances

      • pivot

        public <T extends Model> java.lang.Object pivot(java.lang.String relationshipJoiningTable,
                                                java.lang.String foreignKey,
                                                java.lang.String joiningForeignKey,
                                                T instance,
                                                java.lang.String column)
        Used to access a specific attribute in intermediate table between two model in many-to-many relationship
        Parameters:
        relationshipJoiningTable - the name of relationship joining table
        foreignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for this object
        joiningForeignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for instance model
        instance - the related model instance
        column - column name of attribute
        Returns:
        the value of column in the corresponding row in table

      • pivot

        public <T extends Model> java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> pivot(java.lang.String relationshipJoiningTable,
                                                                                java.lang.String foreignKey,
                                                                                java.lang.String joiningForeignKey,
                                                                                T instance)
        Used to access the intermediate table between two model in many-to-many relationship
        Parameters:
        relationshipJoiningTable - the name of relationship joining table
        foreignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for this object
        joiningForeignKey - the name of foreignKey in relationshipJoiningTable for instance
        instance - the related model instance
        Returns:
        Map containing the values with column name as key of each values
